user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_IdleLoop:
```c
void OS_IdleLoop()
{
    /*
     * Wait until the shutdown value is set to the shutdown number
     * In most "real" embedded systems, this will never happen.
     * However it will happen in debugging situations (CTRL+C, etc).
     */
    while (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        OS_IdleLoop_Impl();
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_IdleLoop:
void OS_IdleLoop_Impl(void)
{
    /*
     * Unblock signals and wait for something to occur
     *
     * Note - "NormalSigMask" was calculated during task init to be the original signal mask
     * of the process PLUS all "RT" signals.  The RT signals are used by timers, so we want
     * to keep them masked here (this is different than the original POSIX impl).  The
     * timebase objects have a dedicated thread that will be doing "sigwait" on those.
     */
    sigsuspend(&POSIX_GlobalVars.NormalSigMask);
}
...
void UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler)
{
    /* Check if the test case registered a hook, and use the default if not */
    if (UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER) == NULL && DefaultHandler != NULL)
    {
        UT_SetHandlerFunction(FuncKey, DefaultHandler, NULL);
    }

    UT_DefaultStubImpl(FunctionName, FuncKey, 0, NULL);
}
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
...
void UT_SetHandlerFunction(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_HandlerFunc_t HandlerFunc, void *UserObj)
{
    UT_HookFuncPtr_t Value;

    Value.SimpleHandler = HandlerFunc;

    UT_DoSetHookFunction(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER, Value, UserObj, false);
}
...
int32 UT_DefaultStubImpl(const char *FunctionName, UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 DefaultRc, ...)
{
    int32   Retcode;
    va_list va;

    va_start(va, DefaultRc);
    Retcode = UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs(FunctionName, FuncKey, DefaultRc, va);
    va_end(va);

    return Retcode;
}
...
OS_SharedGlobalVars_t OS_SharedGlobalVars = {
    .GlobalState     = 0,
    .PrintfEnabled   = false,
    .MicroSecPerTick = 0, /* invalid, _must_ be set by implementation init */
    .TicksPerSecond  = 0, /* invalid, _must_ be set by implementation init */
    .EventHandler    = NULL,
#if defined(OSAL_CONFIG_DEBUG_PRINTF)
    .DebugLevel = 1,
#endif
}
...
#define OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER 0xABADC0DE
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No usage of the Standard Library function memcmp is present in any of the provided code fragments. Specific notes by fragment:
- OS_IdleLoop: compares OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState (an integer) to the numeric constant OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER; no string comparison or memcmp usage.
- OS_IdleLoop_Impl: calls sigsuspend with a signal mask; no string operations or memcmp usage.
- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler: checks the return of UT_GetStubEntry for NULL and DefaultHandler for NULL, and calls UT_SetHandlerFunction / UT_DefaultStubImpl; these are pointer checks and function calls, not string comparisons with memcmp. The parameter FunctionName (const char *) is forwarded but not compared here.
- UT_GetStubEntry: performs integer/hash arithmetic and compares integer fields (EntryType, FuncKey) and array indices; no string comparisons or memcmp usage.
- UT_SetHandlerFunction: assigns a function pointer and calls UT_DoSetHookFunction; no memcmp.
- UT_DefaultStubImpl: uses variadic argument handling (va_list, va_start/va_end) and calls another helper; no memcmp.
- OS_SharedGlobalVars initialization and the OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER macro: these are data initializers/definitions and contain no calls to memcmp.

Therefore, based on the supplied code there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. If there are additional omitted sections (indicated by ellipses) not provided here, those could contain memcmp usage and would need review; but within the provided code none were found.
